key_points: Michigan teachers and students are struggling with fear and anxiety after the Nov. 30 shooting at Oxford High School.
Dozens of Michigan schools received threats of violence, causing widespread disruption and closures.
Teachers are finding their students more concerned about safety, asking about procedures like locking doors.
Plymouth-Canton Community Schools dismissed high schools early due to significant disruption, despite no direct threat being identified.
Teachers across Michigan express tiredness, frustration, and anger over continued gun violence in schools.
Students have questions about their safety and what to do in case of a school shooting, reflecting on ALICE training protocols.
ALICE training, used since the Columbine High School shooting, teaches proactive response strategies to active shooters.
Educators themselves feel unprepared to fully reassure and protect their students.
School districts have implemented various security measures, including new surveillance systems and emergency communication systems.
Teachers are also parents wrestling with how to maintain a sense of normalcy for their own children amidst school threats.
